Dear Lydia Monks,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Forge Dam which we
received on 31/07/2023.
As your request is a request for information relating to the environment,
this has been logged as a request under the Environmental Information
Regulations 2004 (EIR) and will be dealt with under the Regulations. The
reference number for your request can be found above.
The Environmental Information Regulations 2004 state that we must respond
to you within 20 working days, by 29/08/2023. Please do not hesitate to
contact us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Lydia Monks,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Forge Dam
Restoration Project which we received on 31^st July 2023. We apologise for
the significant delay in responding to your request. This was an oversight
on our part.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
We are refusing your request under Regulation 12(4)(b) of the
Environmental Information Regulations 2004 on the grounds that it would be
manifestly unreasonable to comply with the request. We have received six
requests on the same topic within a six-week period and this is one of the
indicators for deciding a request is ‘manifestly unreasonable’.
In addition, we consider it will exceed the cost of compliance which it is
accepted amounts to £450 or 18 hours of officer time. The provision of
correspondence between the Friends of the Porter Valley and Sanctus, with
Sheffield City Council will be time-consuming. We would need to locate the
information, retrieve and extract it. Thereafter we would have to put it
into chronological format and then redact the personal data of the
correspondents. You may recall that we refused a similar request from you
on these same grounds.
Refusing a request as ‘manifestly unreasonable’ does not imply that the
requestor is acting maliciously: it is the term used in the regulations to
cover requests that are excessive and place an unreasonable burden on
resources. We believe this request fits the criteria set out by the
Information Commissioner [1]When can we refuse a request for environmental
information? | ICO
Regulation 12(4)(b) is subject to a public interest test. Factors in
favour of disclosure are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency and helps citizens to understand actions taken by the local
authority.
Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it is not in the
public interest to spend such a large amount of officer time on providing
this information, as this would come at a large cost to the council and
would divert officers from being able to carry out other work. On balance,
the council believes it is a distraction from the core duties of the
council and that the public interest lies in maintaining the exception.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see [2]FOI and
EIR complaints | ICO for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
